did.unittitle: René Jules Dubos papers, Rockefeller University Faculty

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: René Jules Dubos (1901-1982), microbiologist and environmentalist, was affiliated with the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, The Rockefeller University, for more than 50 years (1927-1942 and 1944-1982). During this tenure, Dubos made his most significant contribution to the field of antibiotics with the discovery of gramicidin in 1939. The development, identification, cultivation, and analysis of gramicidin encouraged further experimentation in the field of antibiotics.

René Dubos was born on February 20, 1901 in Saint Brice, France. From 1915 to 1919 he was a student at the College Chaptal in Paris and studied at the Institut National Agronomique from 1919-1921. Dubos received his Ph. D. from Rutgers University in 1927. He became a fellow at the RIMR in that same year and served as a professor from 1957 to 1971, becoming professor emeritus, 1971-1982.

Dubos' environmental activism began in the 1950s, when he urged the scientific community to accept social responsibility for the preservation of the environment. His maxim, "think globally, act locally," became the rallying cry for a generation of environmentalists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials include biographical information, bibliographies, awards and honors, conferences and lectures [agenda and programs], lab notebooks, interviews, clippings, audio and video tapes, photographs, manuscripts, typescripts, galley proofs, correspondence, reprints, reference notes, memorial materials [including letters of condolence to Mrs. Dubos], 80th Birthday Celebration and exhibition, and memorabilia.

Materials highlighting Dubos' work with antibiotics include the lab notebooks, awards and honors, and early reprints. His environmental interests are reflected in the plethora of conferences and lectures in which he participated, articles and books, awards and honors, and manuscripts.
The large number of photographs document Dubos' participation in these varied events, but many also depict aspects of his personal life, capturing Dubos at informal moments and with family members.

list.head: Boxes Eliminated or Box Numbers Reassigned

defitem.item: Box numbers 7-8, formerly photographs circa 1928-1981, have been reassigned to Reference Notes and Reference Materials. The photographs are located in boxes 111-113.
Box 91 was eliminated and the audio tapes were integrated into boxes 105-107
Box 103 was eliminated. Slides from Avery book - placed in RAC slide collection, RG1150, Rm 107 RAC.
The Quest galley proof has been relocated to Box 124. Box 105 reassigned to Audio Tapes

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Boxes 1-104 are partially arranged, in chronological order within subjects. Make Full use of the index to the collection to locate materials. Additions to the collection, boxes 105-132, are standard processed and are arranged by subject and then in chronological order.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Partially arranged. Advanced and Item-Level processing.

accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted pending permission from Rockefeller University.

did.unittitle: Dr. and Mrs. Dubos personal items

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In June 1980 Dr. and Mrs. Dubos sent to the Archives a large group of personal items which included numerous citations; citations with the Honorary Degree Diploma; citations on memberships and prizes and also the statuette presented with the Lasker Award. These have been packed in storage boxes — each box has its own contents lists as well as the listing of the Register. A few items, too large for the storage boxes have been packed in packages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Dubos w/Earl Ubell. WCBS-TV (Spring 1969) May have been filmed on Feb. 19 and aired in spring.
Produced by Osborn Segerberg.
Reporter, Earl Ubell.
On RU campus, coming to work, in Dubos laboratory of environmental biomedicine -.
re destruction of environment, mismanagement of urban life and management of waste.
Deterioration of city - too much noise and crowding.
Cities all over the world more crowded than New York - like Hongkong. Dr. Dubos doesn't consider crowding such a problem - one can have a peaceful, crowded life.
Sameness of environment of city life helps child develop.
Suburban child not exposed to as much as city child.
Children learn to deal with problems.
Management of waterways - air pollution - massive exploration of effects of pollution on children.
Waterfront along East River Drive - R.J. Dubos and Earl Ubell.
